Sure, I can explain the techniques used in the cinematography of these movies.

In "The Revenant", the cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki used a combination of natural light and controlled lighting to create an immersive and realistic visual experience. The film was shot using a combination of wide-angle lenses, aerial shots, and tight close-ups, which helped to capture both the epic scale of the landscape and the intimate details of the characters. Lubezki also used a Steadicam system to allow for smooth, fluid camera movements, which contributed to the film's sense of motion and intensity. In addition, the film was shot in natural light conditions, which required the crew to schedule shoots around the movement of the sun, resulting in a highly authentic visual experience.

In "Birdman", the cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki also used a continuous single take technique to create a sense of urgency and immediacy in the story. The film was designed to look like one long take, achieved through the use of hidden cuts and careful choreography of the camera movements. The cinematography in "Birdman" used a combination of handheld cameras, cranes, and dollies to create the impression of fluid motion and seamless cuts. Lubezki also used a unique lighting approach for "Birdman," where the entire film was lit with practical lights, such as lamps and windows, giving the movie a unique, theatrical feel.

In both films, the cinematography was used as an integral element of the story and played a crucial role in delivering a compelling and immersive experience for the viewer. The use of long takes, fluid camera movements, and natural light helped to create a sense of authenticity and realism, which contributed to the success of the films.
